claim: If you type your PIN number backwards at an ATM, a notification will be sent to the police.

supporting.text: Some banks have implemented emergency PIN reversal systems that alert authorities when a reversed PIN is entered, as a safety feature for victims of coercion.

attacks.text: Some banks have implemented emergency PIN reversal systems that alert authorities when a reversed PIN is entered, as a safety feature for victims of coercion.
Most banks do not have such a system in place, making the claim largely false for the majority of ATM users.
Even if the system exists, it is not widely advertised, so users may not be aware of it and thus cannot rely on it in emergencies.
The system could lead to false alarms if users accidentally enter their PIN backwards, wasting police resources.
Studies show that banks with such systems have seen a measurable decrease in ATM-related crimes, proving their effectiveness.
Banks that implement this feature often provide training or information to customers about how to use it in emergencies.
False alarms are rare because entering a PIN backwards intentionally is highly unlikely to happen by accident.
The decrease in ATM-related crimes could be attributed to other security measures, not necessarily the reversed PIN system.
Even with training, many customers may forget or not pay attention to such specific instructions during a crisis.

supporting.text: There is no widespread evidence or official documentation from major banks confirming that reversed PIN entry triggers police notifications.

attacks.text: There is no widespread evidence or official documentation from major banks confirming that reversed PIN entry triggers police notifications.
Some banks have implemented silent alarm features, including reversed PIN entry, as a security measure for customers under duress.
Even if not officially documented, the reversed PIN feature could be a covert security protocol not publicly disclosed by banks.
Implementing such a feature without public awareness would reduce its effectiveness, as criminals would quickly learn about it through trial and error.
Covert security measures of this nature would likely violate banking transparency regulations and consumer protection laws.
The primary purpose of a duress PIN is to protect the customer, not necessarily to notify police, making widespread documentation unnecessary.
Banking regulations often allow for undisclosed security measures if they enhance customer safety without compromising other legal requirements.

supporting.text: Urban legends and anecdotal reports have perpetuated the idea of reversed PIN alerts, but these lack verification from financial institutions.

attacks.text: Urban legends and anecdotal reports have perpetuated the idea of reversed PIN alerts, but these lack verification from financial institutions.
Some financial institutions have implemented reverse PIN notification systems as a security measure, though they may not publicly disclose this to avoid circumvention.
Anecdotal evidence, while not verified, can sometimes indicate real but undocumented security features that institutions prefer to keep confidential.
Without official confirmation from financial institutions, claims about reverse PIN notifications remain speculative and should not be treated as fact.
The absence of verifiable evidence from credible sources strongly suggests that reverse PIN notifications are a myth rather than a real security feature.
Even if some institutions have such systems, the lack of standardization means the claim cannot be generalized to all ATMs or banks.
Security through obscurity is not a reliable strategy, and financial institutions are more likely to rely on transparent and verifiable security measures.

supporting.text: Implementing such a feature would require coordination between banks and law enforcement, which is not publicly acknowledged or standardized.

attacks.text: Implementing such a feature would require coordination between banks and law enforcement, which is not publicly acknowledged or standardized.
Banks and law enforcement already collaborate on fraud prevention, so such coordination is plausible even if not publicly disclosed.
Standardization is not necessary for individual banks to implement this feature unilaterally as a security measure.
Fraud prevention collaborations are typically documented in public agreements, and no such agreements mention PIN reversal alerts.
Unilateral implementation by banks would create inconsistencies in user experience and security protocols across different ATMs.
Not all collaborations are made public due to security and operational sensitivities, so absence of documentation doesn't prove absence of coordination.
Banks already handle many security features inconsistently (e.g., withdrawal limits), so PIN reversal inconsistency wouldn't be exceptional.

supporting.text: In rare cases, certain ATMs in high-crime areas might have experimental or localized systems that include reversed PIN alerts.

attacks.text: In rare cases, certain ATMs in high-crime areas might have experimental or localized systems that include reversed PIN alerts.
